comments.commentBody: The Yankees fully expect to have Andy back this year, which is why they made no moves for a starting pitcher.  Will he be back, and more importantly, will he be effective quickly, no one really knows.  I truly do not expect both Andy and A-Rod to put on a uniform in September for the first time in 6 to 8 weeks and be productive.  At their age they simply cannot bounce back in two weeks and be ready for the playoffs.

In other words:

Nova does not fill the bill,
Swisher the rally does kill
Grandy's a big K,
Pettite may not play,
The Yankees are over the hill.

I disagree, except for line 4.

There seem to be at least two turnarounds.  There is the good one: Phil Hughes now looking credible and very much like the man who would never be traded.  But then we have Nova, the man who just can't seem to keep his mind on baseball.  Tonight was going to be tough in any case.  Verlander is the likely winner in most matchups.  But Nova again fell apart midway in the game and, as with his previous start, looked to be somewhat irked that he actually had to throw the ball and even wear a uniform amidst all that noise.  I have said several times during this season that we have a deceptive winning record.  I referred to Swisher as a rally killer and was quickly reminded of his HR and RBI output.  Hey, he is a rally killer.  With him and Granderson in the lineup at the same time, it's feast or famine and mostly famine.  Suppose at the start of this season each club could choose between being in the WS or setting a record for homeruns.  Any questions?  Oh, and with Andy gone (maybe for good), we should have paid heavily and got Blanton.
Biggest difference between Hughes and Nova? When the opposing team gets lots of hits, one knows it's because he pitched badly, and the other insists that it was just bad luck.

Mac

Great post.  I would just add that taking a bigger piece of a smaller pie isn't life giving.  It ain't going to last.  The US has tremendous geography on it's side but we aren't managing it very well.  As soon as 75% of our farms are more dust then dirt then we'll be in deep trouble.  and we can thank the Republican Party for it.  by then they'll have moved on to something else.
"In the Soviet Union, capitalism triumphed over communism. In this country, capitalism triumphed over democracy." - Fran Lebowitz

Insightful comments. Thanks. I think you hit Mitt's "personality" right on the head. He is cold and calculating, looking out for himself first. I have come to understand his lying in this context. On the left people say Mitt's a pathological liar or a compulsive liar. They are wrong. Mitt looks at lying as a tool of corporate and/or political strategy, no better or worse than any other tool, with costs and with benefits. The Romney campaign has clearly made the decision that they think lying is to their benefit. Let us hope that the United States of American does not have to pay for their cold-hearted arrogance.

These finance guys are laser focused on the bottom line, Mr. Cohen.

This isn't our father's generation of Conservatives who were crystal clear about the threat of communism to all capitalism. This generation fo Conservatives has other forces entirely to contend with. Russian, China and Vietnam are communist, clearly, yet provide clear sources of inexpensive labor for the Western bottom line. Obviously there is a game change. Western CEOs and financiers embrace their "communist" management elite.

But with the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia the opposite is at work. Western involvement there was revenue, not manufacture and cost saving. The overthrow of Mubarak and even Gaddafi and Assad seem just a threat to their balance sheet, not a benefit.

I can think of no previous period in Western mercantile history quite as perverted as is this one. But it opened with a needless war in Iraq, an argument for which was that it would pay for itself in oil.

One hasn't to reach far to understand the psychology of Mitt Romney' and his investors, Mr. Cohen.

They are colder than ice and as calculating as Lucrezia Borgia could have wished for in descendants. Judging by their nearly openly amoral attitudes one might suspect that their upbringing was as abusively twisted as was hers. But I suspect that Lucrezia is alone among them in being able to call on that history as a defense.

Modern Western Capitalists seem just simply, even egotistically, narcissistically avaricious.

Arnold does your conscience only bother you when you and the conservative GOP cannot control women's reproduction decisions or decree who people can marry? Do you ever feel a twinge of conscience when conservatives fight to repeal the healthcare law, which will continue to force poor children and families to seek expensive and often less effective care in hospital ERs? Are you bothered when conservatives argue for eliminating the U.S. Education department because many of them can afford to spend the equivalent of a good college education to send their children to private k-12 schools? How about the people who lost their homes or are unemployed largely because of the reckless behavior of very wealthy business people who are now spending millions to elect Republicans ready to bend public policy even more in the favor of the very wealthy.

It should be impossible for a person of conscience to vote for a severely conservative Republican.

In many countries in the world no one would have to go through this process as you would not have the option to own this type of weapon. Why do you need it anyway? This is not about "crazies". It is about you.
Obviously Jesus would never own a gun, or vote Republican. Whatever 'religion'  the people you work with may imagine they adhere to, it sure couldn't be the teachings of Jesus Christ.

Many of the guys I know who carry a pistol daily are ex-military D, as am I.

We all made oaths to protect our countries, our way of life and here in the U.S., our Constitution first and foremost. But we'd also protect our friends, families and the citizens in general from guys like this, or Stalin or Saddam, Taking off the uniform, setting aside the daily grind of military life and getting older doesn't kill that oath in us or take away that willingness TO protect people from the two legged animals like Saddam, bin Laden, Wade and Holmes.

It's not the 'guns' that are the problem D, it's crazy men, bent on destruction usually for ideals that only THEY and some small group of nuts truly believe. In a country of 350M, we have maybe 100K white-supremacist skin heads like Wade.

Should I be penalized because of THEIR actions? Are YOU held responsible when some person you don't know kills their wife or friend?

Carroll O'Connor had a GREAT line on the "All in the Family" TV show. His daughter on the show was complaining about 'guns' killing people. He just asked her a simple question...

...would you feel any better if they were shoved out a window little girl?!

It fits here too, it's not the 'way' you kill someone that matters. It's that someone committed a murder that makes it morally and ethically wrong. Did you feel better about all the deaths on 9/11 knowing they weren't shot?

Murder is murder D and the MURDERER is to blame, not the gun, plane, poison or knife.

Agree.  The key isn't the military service, it is the general discharge (and of course the neo-Nazi enthusiasm):  this type of discharge is for misfits who don't actually commit a crime, but are a detriment to the military (perhaps they are convicted of crimes under local civilian jurisdiction).  No ex-service member with less than an Honorable Discharge should be eligible to buy a weapon.  It may seem unfair, because we don't have a draft and most people don't serve at all, but the military is good at vetting, so if they push someone out, let us make use of that information to protect ourselves. Of course the TImes devotes too much ink to showing that veterans are all a group of misfits, suicidal depressives, wife beaters, drunks, homeless, and so forth.  It isn't news, it's skewed sociology.

That's simply not supported by data in the "Uniform Crime Report", and that's a reference published by Eric Holder's Justice Department -- I'm sure you don't consider him a racist.

The only meager support for your (despicably racist) assertion is that white-on-black crime is often categorized as "hate crime", while black-on-white crime virtually never is. I'll direct your attention to, for example, the statistics on white-on-black vs. black-on-white rape. You need to read a bit more, further your education, and abandon your racism.

Do you want the police or army or marines or national guard to go in to every residence and business to find and confiscate the guns?

Norway has very strict laws against hate speech as well as gun control and neither prevented the massacre of  77 people -mostly children- last summer. Every one of these shootings -both in the U.S. and abroad- involves a despondent male who blames society for his failures and decides to take revenge.  If there were no guns, if we were all the same color and practiced the same religion, these shooters would simply find another justification to kill.  To prevent these tragedies, western society needs to teach responsibility - even in the face of despair.  There is great honor in humbly admitting defeat and starting anew.  In our ever increasing consumerist culture, we have forgotten to teach this.

The reason we allow hate speech in the U.S. is because the First Amendment is pretty broad, and because our system of justice and values assumes there is an on/off switch between thought and action.. Sadly, its too late when we find out that switch is broken in some people.

Does hate filled rhetoric provide enough rationale to pause before letting someone buy a gun? Or will it just stop those too stupid to keep their bad chemistry to themselves?

Because, young man, it is every law abiding citizen's right to buy a gun as long as the store clerk is willing to sell it to him. I am quite confident he didn't walk into a gun store and say "Hi, I am clinically insane and a white supremist, can I have a semi-automatic hunting rifle?" If he said that, then the store owner would have turned him away just as the gun club owner turned away the Colorado nut-job.
The real question is, why don't we have a test to determine if someone is legally sane and not a criminal, the same way we require a driver's test to own a motor vehicle?
Oh, one more thing young man. Ignore the partisan rants on this web page by the extreme left who want to blame this tragedy on "whites" or "repubs" or "right wingers." It is simply the work of a single mad man and not some "vast conspiracy"

He (and other mass murderers) bought not just one gun, but could have purchased many.

"Page lived in North Carolina before moving to the Milwaukee area and was issued five separate gun purchase permits in North Carolina after passing a background check in May 2008, according to the Cumberland County, North Carolina, sheriff's office."

http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/07/us-usa-wisconsin-shooting-weap...

Somebody like what? There's the rub? There's probably hundreds of thousands of racist gun-owners out there. How in the world can you identify the one or two that will commit horrific violence? I don't know how to prevent these tragedies. I know this, though: we won't even begin to make a dent in this problem until we change our attitudes about guns in the country.

I told my 13-year-old son today about this rampage. I mentioned that the shooter was a white supremacist. He immediately said, "why can someone like that buy a gun?"

Can anyone here answer him for me?

Indeed, this country has changed for the worse. I grew up in a Jewish family in a very Christian neighborhood in New Mexico. Neighbors invited us over to help decorate their tree; we shared menorah candle-lighting with them. All this hate was unknown, and unaccepted. Now -- it's rampant. What has happened? WHAT has happened? I blame the far right for their fanatical, uncompromising rhetoric and their filling the air waves with hate and self-righteousness.

Sorry Dave, I don't buy the idea that there is no explanation for violent racism in America.  No excuse, sure.  But look at the way the right wing demonizes the 'other' day after day after day, from talk radio to Fox News to the halls of Congress.,

I don't think America has regressed significantly. Some Americans, motivated by fear, have regressed, or would like America to regress. But on the whole, America keeps moving in the right direction, toward equality of opportunity for all. I truly believe this, just as I truly believe it is important to vote against those who would move us backward.

As a Muslim, together with family and friends here in Lahore, Pakistan, I stand in prayer for the grieving families. May Allah give health to the wounded and courage to those who have lost loved ones.

Apart from gun control and the spread of interfaith literacy at the primary school level, tolerance needs to be promoted. America seems to have regressed significantly on this account.

The America that I had experienced in the 1970s was remarkably different. In 1977 my neighbor, 84 years old Mrs. Freedman insisted on feeding me on the occasion of Eid-ul-Fitr, she had found out that I did not have family in the US.
Your last paragraph, sir: brilliant. Unassailable. I wish I knew your last name, because I'd look you up and invite you out for a drink. We'd have a great conversation...

Mr. Sorkin you got it exactly right. As you said:

"Individuals are worried that it’s hard to make the right bet and worried that the market is rigged against them. Much of this is an outgrowth of woes of Wall Street’s own making, like insider trading cases or market manipulation scandals."

Amen. I'm not only worried that the market is rigged, I'm absolutely convinced. And who wouldn't be? It seems that every day there's another Wall Street scandal that can be simply explained by corrupt and greedy behavior. Behavior that is somehow legal in the western world.

If you steal a loaf of bread, you'll likely be punished by the legal system. But if you steal millions or billions on Wall Street you'll likely get a nice fat severance package.

Unfortunately the problems are much deeper than Wall Street. These wealthy Wall Street oligarchs now own governments all over the world, which explains why the legal system has no teeth. This is the final nail in the coffin. Unless and until this is fixed, we can expect more frequent financial collapses.

And so, I'll just sit on the sidelines, thank you. At 58 years old, I can't take anymore giant losses due to the corrupt behaviors of Wall Street and our so called representatives in Washington.

This is patient advocacy at its best! Way to go Mr. Tomlinson. As a fellow RN, I salute you. You did us proud.

By the way, I called the Board of Licensure in Florida and was told by someone there that there is nothing they can do about a medical assistant stating "I'm a nurse" as long as they don't say "I'm a RN", or "I'm a LPN". There is nothing in Florida's legislation that prohibits a medical assistant from passing themselves off as "a nurse" I was even told that in Florida Med Techs can call themselves "nurses" again as long as they don't say. RN or LPN. Some doctors will let you just assume that his assistant is his nurse. It is much more cost effective for a doctor to hire a medical assistant than to pay for a RN or LPN. Do you really believe that a patient, especially an elderly one would think to ask "What kind of nurse are you?" " What are your credentials?
Laws are different in each and every state, so again make sure you're talking to a RN or LPN when it about your illness, treatments, meds. Let the assistants take your BP, weigh you, etc, but do not ask them for any medical advise.
Remember healthcare is a business, and with another business the bottom line is all important, make sure your getting what you paid for.

Frances Donovan
